abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Third Population
            Project for Kenya was unsatisfactory. The project achieved
            some of its objectives, institutional development was
            negligible, sustainability is uncertain, and the performance
            of the Bank was marginally satisfactory while the
            Borrower's was unsatisfactory. Several lessons can be
            learned from this project. First, it is better to
            restructure a project instead of developing a new one with
            similar objectives. Second, when the Borrower's
            procurement capacity is deficient, the use of an outside
            procurement agent should be considered at an early stage.
            Third, future operations should focus on ensuring clear and
            effective implementation and management arrangements,
            particularly in financial accountability. Fourth, unless a
            better implementation arrangement for construction can be
            established, civil works should be kept to a minimum in
            future operations, focusing primarily on rehabilitation or
            upgrading. Fifth, the need for adequate supervision,
            including field visits by both the Bank and Borrower, cannot
            be overemphasized. Sixth, in future operations where NGOs
            will be used, GOK needs to improve NGO coordination and NGOs
            need to strengthen their financial accountability. Finally,
            training programs should be better prioritized and staff
            sent only on training in areas of identified needs and where
            there is a clear prospect that the training will help the
            project or sector.
